content: How can I help you today?

Well, I’ve been having a lot of trouble sleeping lately. Work has been really stressful, and I can’t stop worrying about possibly getting fired. It’s been keeping me up at night, and I just don’t know how to shut off all these thoughts. My partner insisted I come here, so I’m trying to keep an open mind.

It sounds like you're dealing with a lot right now—stress at work, worries about your job security, and it's affecting your sleep. Hearing how heavy this has all been for you, it's understandable you'd feel overwhelmed. It’s great that you’re staying open to talking about it, even under such challenging circumstances. What do you feel is the biggest obstacle to finding some relief right now?

I think the biggest obstacle is my own mind. Like, I can't seem to stop the spiral of thoughts once I start worrying. Every time I try to fall asleep, my brain just replays all the things that could go wrong, and it feels relentless. I don’t even know where to begin to stop it.

It sounds exhausting to be caught in that spiral, especially when you're trying to rest. The constant replay of all the "what ifs" can take a toll when it feels like you have no control over it. Acknowledging how relentless it feels is an important step, and it shows a lot of self-awareness. Have there been any moments, even small ones, where you've been able to quiet those thoughts, or do they feel constant throughout the day?

Honestly, it feels like they’re with me all the time. During the day, I can push through because I’m busy, but as soon as I’m in bed and everything is quiet, it’s like my brain just turns up the volume. It’s draining.

It sounds like the busyness of the day helps you keep the worries at bay, but at night, when there's nothing to distract you, they feel overwhelming. That level of exhaustion must be really hard to deal with, especially when you're already stressed from work. It’s clear how much this has been weighing on you. What do you think might help you regain some sense of calm, even in those quiet moments?

I don’t really know. I’ve tried things like watching TV or scrolling on my phone to distract myself, but that only helps for a little while, and then it’s back to the same racing thoughts. I guess I just wish I could shut my brain off long enough to fall asleep.

It sounds like you've been trying some ways to distract yourself, but they haven’t provided lasting relief, especially when the thoughts keep coming back. Wanting to quiet your mind long enough to sleep sounds like a really common feeling for someone handling stress like you have been. Have you noticed if anything you’ve tried has helped even a little, or are there moments during the day when you've felt more peaceful? Maybe we can explore how those moments happen together.

It’s tough when distractions only help temporarily, and it’s understandable to feel stuck like that. Sometimes finding what helps can take some experimenting, and it sounds like you’re willing to try. Is there anything during the day—maybe when you’re with your kids or doing something you enjoy—that feels like it brings even a small sense of calm?

Actually, I don’t have kids, and right now, it’s hard to think of anything that brings me a sense of calm. With work stress and not sleeping, I haven’t really found much time to do things I enjoy lately. I feel like I’m just stuck in this cycle.

Sorry, I misspoke earlier—I do have two kids. And now that I think about it, spending time with them can sometimes help me take my mind off things for a while. They’re so full of energy and just living in the moment, it’s hard not to get caught up in that a little. But as soon as they’re asleep, all the stress comes flooding back.

Being with your kids seems like a bright spot for you, even amidst everything you're going through. Their energy and presence sound like a welcome distraction, pulling you into the moment, even if only for a little while. It's tough when the sense of calm fades once they're asleep, and it seems like you're back to carrying everything alone again. What do you think keeps you grounded during those moments with them? Is there anything about that time you’d want more of?

I think what keeps me grounded is how happy and carefree they are—they remind me of what really matters, you know? Spending time with them just kind of forces me to focus on them and not my own worries for a little bit. I’d love to have more of those moments, but with work stress and everything else, I feel like I’m not really able to be fully present with them the way I want to be.

Your kids seem to bring a kind of clarity and joy that helps you refocus, even if it’s just for a moment. Having that time feels really meaningful to you, but it also feels like the weight of work and stress is making it harder for you to fully engage. It sounds like you deeply value being present with them—it’s important to you—but balancing that with everything else has been really challenging. What would it mean to you if you could create more space for moments like that, even with the stress around you?

It would mean everything to me. I want to be the best parent I can be and give them the love and attention they deserve. But it’s so hard to let go of my stress when I’m worried about keeping my job and providing for them. I feel like I’m stretched so thin and don’t know how to balance it all.

You're carrying so much right now—your worries about work, your love for your kids, and the desire to give them the best of yourself. It’s heartbreaking to feel stretched so thin when you're trying to manage everything that's important to you, and it shows just how deeply you care about being there for them. That sense of balance feels like something you're longing for. What do you think could be a first step toward easing just a bit of that pressure?

You're carrying so much right now—your worries about work, your love for your kids, and the desire to give them the best of yourself. It’s heartbreaking to feel stretched so thin when you're trying to manage everything that's important to you, and it shows just how deeply you care about being there for them. That sense of balance feels like something you're longing for. What do you think could be a first step toward easing just a bit of that pressure?

It’s hard to even say what that first step should be. I know something has to change, but every time I think about trying to make a change, I feel overwhelmed by everything else I’m already juggling. I’m not really sure where to start.

It makes sense that figuring out where to start feels overwhelming when you're under so much pressure already. When everything feels like so much, even the thought of change can feel like another thing to add to the pile. Maybe we can try breaking it into smaller steps—what’s one thing, even something really simple, that you feel like is within your control right now?

Well, I guess one thing I could try is carving out even just a few minutes each day to focus on myself—maybe taking a short walk or sitting quietly for a bit to clear my mind. It’s not something I’ve really been doing, but it feels like it could be manageable. Maybe that could help me start moving in the right direction.
